title: HIV and Sexual Responsibility

content: Talking about sex and how to protect yourself from sexually transmitted diseases shouldn’t be taboo or challenging. But it often is.
It can be easier to rely on misinformation instead of taking time to get educated about the topic. But that builds even more stigma around HIV and AIDS and active, healthy sex lives.
Even though there’s plenty of information to help you protect yourself, many people don’t take advantage of it. So they enter risky sexual situations without knowing how to stay safe.
Regardless of how uncomfortable it may be to ask questions about HIV status, testing, and sexual practices, sexual health is everyone’s responsibility.

When living with HIV, the focus on personal responsibility is greater and more significant than ever, for multiple reasons. Because of how stigmatizing it can be to disclose your HIV status, doing so means taking a risk. There's the possibility of being rejected by someone you’re interested in dating or having as a sex partner.

content: Having lived with HIV for more than 20 years, I've had plenty of situations where I had to ask potential sex partners about their status and when they were last tested. As uncomfortable and frightening as it was, I had to develop the courage to be transparent with them about my HIV status and when I was last tested for STIs.

Most of the time, those conversations went well and led to more free-flowing experiences and communication. Other times, what I disclosed was a deal breaker. I'll be honest – each time I was rejected because of my HIV status, it became easier for me to accept the situation and move on.
Because, at the end of the day, I have to be proud of myself for honoring and living in my truth. With no shame.

There are also very real concerns about backlash, including violence, as a result of disclosing your HIV status. This can even lead to prosecution linked to HIV criminalization laws, which vary from state to state. There are times people have been wrongfully charged, prosecuted, and imprisoned because of these laws, which continue to stigmatize and polarize people living with HIV in cruel and harmful ways.

content: For example, let’s say someone living with HIV who’s undetectable (meaning they're unable to pass along HIV to anyone through sexual contact) has consensual sex with another adult, without disclosing their status. Depending on laws in their state, they could be arrested as a result.

This isn't to suggest you should conceal or withhold information about your HIV status. But in cases like this, it's important to note that even if you disclose your status before sex, the other person could later accuse you of not doing so.

Regardless of whether you’re HIV-positive or negative, having conversations about sexual health is your responsibility. Yes, it can be awkward. But it’s important to develop the skills to be open, honest, and courageous. Not only does this help you be more secure in who you are, it normalizes asking hard questions and accepting their answers.
What’s most important is to be armed with information. From there, you have not only a responsibility, but an opportunity to make informed decisions that protect yourself and your partners.
